prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The requested sensitivity is sufficient to detect the Meurer et al. (1999)-predicted flux densities of every target at S/N > 3. The sensitivity was then slightly improved to optimize the ratio of on-source time to overheads, resulting in a median predicted S/N of 7.7. The half-light radii of galaxies at z ~ 6-8 are typically ~0.2" (Ono et al. 2013, Jiang et al. 2013), so we request an angular resolution of 0.6" to avoid significant beam dilution. The modified blackbody spectrum of our targets is expected to fall rapidly towards lower frequencies, so the central continuum frequency has been shifted to 265 GHz to maximize the expected S/N.

The requested sensitivity is sufficient to detect the Meurer et al. (1999)-predicted flux densities of every target at S/N > 3. The sensitivity was then slightly improved to optimize the ratio of on-source time to overheads, resulting in a median predicted S/N of 6.3. The half-light radii of galaxies at z ~ 6-8 are typically ~0.2" (Ono et al. 2013, Jiang et al. 2013), so we request an angular resolution of 0.6" to avoid significant beam dilution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Little has been measured about recently discovered populations of Lyman-break galaxies during the epoch of cosmic reionization at z > 6 outside of the rest-frame UV. However, observations at lower redshifts or of much larger systems, such as quasar hosts, have shown that a significant component of a galaxy's bolometric luminosity can be found in the rest-frame FIR and indicate a substantial amount of obscured star formation. The FIR can additionally constrain the buildup of dust in the high-redshift interstellar medium and help differentiate the physics there from that at lower redshift. We propose to make the first measurements in this critically important band of a sample of "normal" (roughly L*) star-forming galaxies at the earliest redshifts currently known.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
